text.content:
Movement & Travel

Rules for moving and traveling in D&D

Speed

Every creature has a Speed, which is the distance in feet you can walk in 1 round (6 seconds). Your Speed can be modified by:

  • Armor (heavy armor may reduce Speed)
  • Terrain (difficult terrain costs extra movement)
  • Conditions (Grappled, Prone, etc.)
  • Spells and magic items

Types of Movement

Walk Speed

Your basic Speed. Standard for most humanoids is 30 feet.

Climb Speed

Allows you to climb without extra movement cost. Without a Climb Speed, climbing costs 2 feet of movement per 1 foot climbed.

Swim Speed

Allows you to swim without extra movement cost. Without a Swim Speed, swimming costs 2 feet of movement per 1 foot swam.

Fly Speed

Allows you to fly. If you have a Fly Speed and are knocked Prone, you fall unless you can hover.

Burrow Speed

Allows you to burrow through sand, earth, mud, or ice, leaving no tunnel behind unless specified.

Moving in Combat

  • On your turn, you can move up to your Speed
  • You can split your movement before, during, and after actions
  • Moving through a hostile creature's space requires Athletics or Acrobatics check
  • Moving out of an enemy's reach provokes Opportunity Attacks (unless you Disengage)

Difficult Terrain

Every 1 foot of movement in difficult terrain costs 2 feet of Speed.

Examples: Rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, shallow bogs

Being Prone

  • Standing up: Costs half your Speed (minimum 5 feet)
  • Crawling: Every foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (total 2 feet per foot)
  • In combat: Attack rolls against you have Advantage; your attacks have Disadvantage

Jumping

Long Jump

  • With 10-foot running start: Jump a number of feet up to your Strength score
  • From standing: Jump half that distance
  • Each foot you jump costs 1 foot of movement

High Jump

  • With 10-foot running start: Jump 3 + Strength modifier feet high
  • From standing: Jump half that distance
  • Can reach above jump height by half your height

Forced March: After 8 hours of travel, make DC 10 + 1 per hour beyond 8 Constitution save or gain 1 Exhaustion.

Mounts and Vehicles

  • Controlled Mount: Acts on your turn, can only Dash, Disengage, or Dodge
  • Independent Mount: Acts on its own turn, retains all actions
  • Mounted Combat: Special rules for attacks and damage
